reviewText: WCW's Starrcade 97 should have been WCW's shining moment, the night when WCW took back control of the sport from Hollywood Hulk Hogan and the goons of the NWO, but the climax of the match eighteen months in the making - the return of the dark and mysterious Sting to face Hogan for the world's heavyweight championship - is in many ways a tragedy that disappointed and almost ruined my entire viewing experience.  Overall, though, the night's events are pretty exciting and unpredictable, with three major titles on the line and control of the Monday Nitro telecast up for grabs, making this a worthwhile tape to own despite rather than because of the Sting-Hogan match.Starrcade 97 shows unexpected weakness early on, as Bobby the Brain Heenan is a no-show, leaving us with an announcing crew made up of Tony Schiavone, the American Dream Dusty Rhodes, and Mike Tenay.  Kevin Nash, it is announced, will also not be there to face the Giant.  The first match, though, is a good one.  Dean Malenko tries to regain the cruiserweight belt from Eddy Guerrero, and despite the fact I always hated Guerrero, he was pretty impressive in the ring on this night.  After this first match, the NWO's Scott Hall comes out to do his little survey of WCW vs NWO fans in the audience and to let everyone know that Kevin Nash will not be there to fight the Giant.  We do get a little satisfaction from this turn of events, though, when the Giant comes out and basically leaves Scott Hall lying unconscious in the middle of the ring.  Next up is a six-man tag team match: WCW tag team champions Scott and Rick Steiner team up with Ray Traylor take on the NWO's Scott Norton, Vincent, and Konan - except Konan isn't there, and Randy Macho Man Savage takes his place.  There really isn't a lot to say about this somewhat uninspired six-man tag event.  The next matchup is also rather disappointing: Steve Mongo McMichael takes on relative newcomer Goldberg; this Goldberg is a far cry from the man who would soon thereafter soar into the stratosphere of wrestling success and popularity.  There's one more match to go through before getting to the good stuff.  In what had already become a tiring storyline, Raven comes out and has a member of his "flock" (in this case, Saturn) take on Chris Benoit in his place.From this point on, the WCW-NWO struggle all comes together.  First, Lex Lugor takes on the NWO's Buff Bagwell in a pretty disappointing match with an exciting ending featuring a little outside interference.  Next, Diamond Dallas Page gets his shot at taking the US championship belt away from Curt Hennig of the NWO.  This fight isn't anything that special, and the ending, while certainly satisfying, comes off a little clumsy.  Still, DDP always generated a lot of excitement, and he took a big bite out of destiny on this night.  Control of Monday Nitro hangs in the balance when Larry Zbyszko, the Living Legend himself, returns to the ring to take on WCW boss and traitor Eric Bischoff.  Bret Hart, a man of questionable loyalties, serves as the special referee, and he plays a big part in the fight's outcome.  The match itself was pretty lousy; Legend did not look very good at all, and when he did start wailing on Bischoff, Hart kept making him stop (much to the chagrin of our announcing trio, especially an unusually blood-thirsty Tony Schiavone).  Naturally, the NWO tries to take a shortcut to victory in the form of a loaded boot, but the man they thought was on their side, Bret Hart, not only declares Legend the winner, he knocks Bischoff out like a light and puts Scott Hall in the painful Sharpshooter hold for some time, leaving him lying in the middle of the ring for a second time that night.Then comes the moment the wrestling world had been waiting for.  After eighteen months of mystery and unanswered questions, Sting returns to the ring to fight Hogan for the world's heavyweight championship.  Month after month fans had waited to find out just whose side the Stinger was on and just what was going on inside his head.  After all that hard work, WCW managed to screw up the match itself.  Sting is not exactly king of the ring that night, and Hogan beats him rather easily, with controversial referee Nick Patrick delivering a legitimate 1-2-3 count.  Bret Hart suddenly shows up again, though, refuses to let anyone ring the bell, and throws Hogan back in the ring in order to restart the match.  You can imagine what happens.  WCW fans are jubilant, Dusty Rhodes and Tony Schiavone are bursting at the seams with glee, all the WCW wrestlers come to the ring in a show of unity for the hero who has returned and cut the head off the NWO monster, and I sat there saying, "What a gyp."  I was pretty disgusted that WCW would let the climax of so much time and effort end in such a silly manner.  Starrcade 97 is, on the whole, a better than average PPV, but the Sting-Hogan match taints all of the good matches that preceded it.
summary: WCW, in its finest hour, decides to shoot itself in the foot
Title: N/A

reviewText: You know that little footnote you see at the bottom of the screen whenever there is a PPV advertisement that says "CARD SUBJECT TO CHANGE?  Well this PPV is a perfect example of what that footnote means because of most of the card & PPV format was changed as WCW saved some of their advertised matches for the Souled Out PPV the next month.  To continue a storyline that happened on the previous Nitro, Bobby Heenan didn't do the color commentary for the PPV as it was the team of Tenay, Tony, and Dusty.  Last but not least, the advertised match between Kevin Nash vs. Giant was cancelled because Kevin Nash no-showed (which was never explained why).  This would have been possibly one of the best WCW shows of all time but they dropped the ball by not delivering what they advertised & hyped up for weeks.  Plus the long awaited Hogan vs. Sting match left a bad taste in everyone's mouth (and that's put it lightly).Crusierweight Champion Eddie Guerrero vs. Dean Malenko - This was very similar to their series in ECW and a great way to begin the program with their mat wrestling.In order for WCW to save face for Nash's no show, Scott Hall came out to talk to the crowd before Giant showed up & left him lying with Kevin Nash's "Jackknife" powerbomb.  The Nash/Giant match would happen at Souled Out the next month.Steiner Brothers & Ray Traylor [WCW] vs. Randy Savage, Vincent, Scott Norton [nWo] - Randy Savage replaced Konnan and this was a good match for what it was but it's nothing special here.  The six-man tag with Konnan would end up taking place the next month at Souled Out.Steve "Mongo" McMichael vs. Goldberg - This was at the start of Goldberg's career where his matches didn't have the crowd chanting his name, he didn't have a winning streak, and didn't have those quick fast-paced matches that lasted 4 mins.  Some of the storyline heat for this match was gone since Debra McMichael (Mongo's ex-wife & the woman who hired Goldberg to go after McMichael) left WCW weeks before the PPV.  The match wasn't anything special since Goldberg was still green while McMichael wasn't good enough in the ring to carry anyone.  It's watchable but nothing special.Chris Benoit vs. Saturn - The storyline here was that Raven didn't want to wrestle Chris Benoit so for the next month on Monday Nitro & Saturday Night, Raven would send in a member of his flock to wrestle for him.  Well, they did it here too as Raven send in Saturn to wrestle.  This was a good match & the best the announcers were at calling a match all night as they kept pointing out that Saturn was working on Benoit's neck instead of his usual plan of working the arms.  This match ended with the usual interference from Raven's flock & Raven DDTing Benoit on his neck before Saturn won the match.  Again, they saved the Raven/Benoit match for next month's PPV.Lex Luger vs. Buff Bagwell - The story here was that Buff Bagwell defeated Luger every time they faced by either disqualification or countout.  This match was long & dry for the most part until the ending when the nWo members from the six man tag earlier interfered helping Bagwell pin Luger setting up Luger's feud with Savage for the next couple of months.United States Champion Curt Hennig vs. DDP - This was scheduled to be a steel cage match between Ric Flair & Curt Hennig to finish out their storyline but Flair was taken out two weeks earlier & DDP was inserted into the match.  The match itself was pretty good as DDP gave the crowd what they wanted & became a champion for the first time since his babyface turn a year ago.Larry Zbyszko [WCW] vs. Eric Bischoff w/Scott Hall [nWo]. Special Referee: Bret "Hitman" Hart - This was suppose to be a match where you can win by submission or knockout & Monday Nitro was on the line plus if Larry Zbyszko wins, he gets a match with Scott Hall at Souled Out.  This "match" was all about one thing...who is Bret Hart going to side with?  Throughout the whole match, there was stalling by Bischoff & Hart whenever Zbyszko would get momentum in his direction. The end came when Bret finally punched Bischoff & took out call while Zbyszko choked Bischoff before Bret declared Zbyszko the winner.  This was a flop.WCW Champion Hollywood Hogan vs. Sting - This was the match that made this Starrcade the most watched PPV in WCW history.  The match itself was good until the very end as Nick Patrick did a normal 3 count on Sting that everyone tried to sell as a fast count.  The fans were booing & nobody was buying the "fast count" until Bret Hart came out implying he wasn't going to have another "Montreal Screwjob" and restarted the match to have Sting beat Hogan.  This was built up for over a year & the fans wanted to see Sting beat Hogan cleanly. They would do the exact same match the next night on Nitro before Sting was stripped was of the World Title.  This was the defining moment for WCW & they blew it because everyone was talking about that crappy ending more than Sting winning the belt in the end or the match itself.In the end, this is a show I can watch again but I just remember seeing it the first time & wanting a refund because WCW took advantage of it's audience because they got your money instead of giving what they had advertised & what the audience wanted.  This is a tape worth renting (if you can find it for rent) & then seeing if it's worth buying but if your not sure then I suggest you go ahead & save your cash.
summary: WCW RUINED The Biggest Show In It's History!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This title was labeled as Starrcade 1997 when in reality it contains Starrcade 1996. Misprints also occured with the covers and labels for Starrcade 1995, 1997, World War 3 1995, 1996, 1997. Alot of sellers are not aware of this as they just buy and sell titles for profit rather than actually being a die hard wrestling fan and or reviewing product before reselling it. The U.K. DVD cover posted here is not the same as the original U.S. video box cover. The back cover is totally different. Not having viewed the U.K. DVD rerelease I would hazard a guess that the content has also been altered and or edited. BEWARE OF WHAT THIS U.K. DVD VERSION ACTUALLY CONTAINS !
Title: N/A

reviewText: Even though it says Starrcade 1997, this is actually a review for Starrcade 1996 because that's when Piper and Hogan went at it at Starrcade.  Here's the match listing:Ultimo Dragon vs Dean Malenko for the WCW Cruiserweight title:  Boy what a great way to start the PPV with this classic between two of the best in the world at that time.  Dragon actually came in with 8 other Cruiserweight and Junior Heavyweight titles that he won at the 1996 Super J Crown Tournament.  This was a very good wrestling match with ariel manevers thrown in for good measure.  All in all this may have been the match of the night.  I give this match a 10/10.Madusa vs Akira Hokuto for the new WCW Women's title:  This was a good match between two of the best women wrestlers of that era.  It wasn't too short and it wasn't too long, just a nice paced match from start to finish.  I give this match a 7/10.Rey Mysterio vs Jushin Liger:  This was dream match for many fans of wrestling and it did not disappoint.  This match could also claim to be match of the night as they attempted to steal the show and may have just done that.  This match was awesome and well worth the purchase of this PPV alone.  I give this match 10/10.Chris Benoit vs Jeff Jarrett:  This was a good match but I didn't like the fact that Jarrett won.  Him winning just ruined the whole match for me.  I give this match a 7/10.Outsiders vs Faces of Fear for the WCW Tag titles:  On paper I thought this match was going to suck but in reality it wasn't too bad.  I knew with Hall and Nash's power within the company that Meng and Barbarian wasn't going to win but it was still a fun and enjoyable match to watch.  I have always been a huge mark for the Barbarian (I don't know why) so this match was extra special for me.  I give this match a 8/10.DDP vs Eddie Guerrero for the vacant WCW US title:  This was a great match between these two.  Eddie could really have a match with almost anybody and make them look good but Page was very good in this match.  This was kind of his rise to glory at this time as he had turned his back on the NWO and paid for it during this match.  Everything was good about this match so i give this match a 9/10.The Giant vs Lex Luger:  This was a decent match. There wasn't a whole lot of "Oh my God" moments but it was what it was.  One thing to look for in this match is Sting making an appearance and whispering something in both men's ears.  Good match.  I give this match a 7/10.Main Event:  Hulk Hogan vs Roddy Piper in a non title match:  Really good match.  Still can't figure out why they sold this PPV on a non title headline.  I think when u pay for a PPV u should get a world title main event match.  This match was very cool, it was like stepping back in time to the 80's to see these two go at it again.  Some people just can't figure out why people were so into this match, well I think a lot of it was that chance to go back and relieve it all over again.  It was War to Settle the Score and Wrestlemania to some people all over.  For others like me who were too young to remember these matches it was a chance to see these two icons go at and give it their all.  They really did do that for the fans, it was a lot of fun to see these two "lock horns."All in all this was a very good PPV.  There was really nothing that I would have changed on this card just to make the main event a title match and that was it.  I would give this PPV as a whole a 9/10.  Well worth checking out!!
Title: N/A
